text: Everyone knew of ChatGPT, but when you clicked one zoom level further, the thing that came up was, 'I don't know what to use it for. I don't know what it replaces. Should I be using search for this? Should I be using ChatGPT for this? How can it even help me?' And so the work of marketing ended up becoming creating this sort of use case epiphany where people could say, 'I had no idea ChatGPT can do that. And yeah, maybe I should be using it for X, Y, Z reason in my own life.'
speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
context: Lenny asks Krithika about the value that marketing adds to a product like ChatGPT, which seems so magical that it wouldn't need marketing support. Krithika explains that while awareness wasn't the problem for ChatGPT - everyone had heard of it - the real challenge was helping people understand practical applications. The marketing team's role became creating moments of realization where users discovered new ways to incorporate ChatGPT into their daily workflows and decision-making processes.
text_ko: 모두가 ChatGPT를 알고는 있었어요. 그런데 한 단계만 더 들어가 보면 사람들이 흔히 하는 말이, "이걸 뭘 위해 써야 하지? 뭘 대체하는 거지? 검색(search)을 써야 하나, ChatGPT를 써야 하나? 이게 어떻게 도움을 주지?" 같은 거였어요. 그래서 마케팅은 결국 사람들이 "어? ChatGPT가 이런 것도 할 수 있구나. 아, 내 생활에서 X, Y, Z 이유로 이걸 써봐야겠다"라고 느끼게 해주는, 일종의 사용 사례의 깨달음(use case epiphany)을 만들어내는 일이 됐어요.
text_zh: 大家都知道ChatGPT这个东西，但你再深入了解一下就会发现，用户其实会说："我也不知道拿它干什么用啊，不知道它能替代什么。这种情况我是该用搜索还是该用ChatGPT？它到底能帮我什么忙？" 所以营销的重点就变成了要给用户创造一种恍然大悟的感觉，让他们说："哇，原来ChatGPT还能这么用！对啊，我在自己生活中确实应该用它来做这些那些事情。"
text_es: Todo el mundo conocía ChatGPT, pero cuando profundizabas un poquito más, lo que salía a la luz era: 'No tengo ni idea de para qué usarlo. No sé qué está reemplazando. ¿Debería usar el buscador para esto? ¿O debería usar ChatGPT? ¿Cómo me puede ayudar siquiera?' Entonces el trabajo de marketing terminó siendo crear como una especie de momento eureka de casos de uso, donde la gente pudiera decir: 'No tenía ni idea de que ChatGPT podía hacer eso. Y sí, tal vez debería estar usándolo por tal, tal y tal razón en mi propia vida.'

text: A lot of marketing metrics tend to be vanity metrics about the number of clicks that you got, number of views, number of impressions. I think those are all bullshit numbers. What is that experience that you want your customers to come away with when they interact with your brand?
speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
context: During her introduction, Krithika discusses the common problem with marketing measurement and focus. She argues against focusing on surface-level engagement metrics like clicks, views, and impressions, calling them meaningless. Instead, she advocates for measuring the actual customer experience and the lasting impression that interactions with your brand create. This reflects her philosophy that marketing should focus on meaningful outcomes rather than vanity metrics that look good in reports but don't drive real business value.
text_ko: 많은 마케팅 지표들이 클릭 수, 조회수, 노출 수처럼 보여주기 식의 허영 지표(vanity metrics)인 경우가 많아요. 저는 그런 건 전부 의미 없는 숫자들이라고 생각해요. 브랜드와 상호작용했을 때 고객이 어떤 경험을 얻어가길 원하나요?
text_zh: 很多营销指标其实都是虚荣指标(vanity metrics)，就是点击量啊、浏览量啊、曝光量啊这些。我觉得这些数据都是扯淡。关键是你希望客户和你的品牌接触后能有什么样的体验感受？
text_es: Muchas de las métricas de marketing suelen ser métricas de vanidad (vanity metrics) sobre cuántos clics conseguiste, cuántas visualizaciones, cuántas impresiones. Yo creo que todos esos números son pura patraña. ¿Cuál es esa experiencia que quieres que tus clientes se lleven cuando interactúan con tu marca?

text: So I was an engineer before I became a marketer, and so I have brought a little bit of an engineer's framework to the marketing side of the house. And so something that I've tried to do is put together a four-step process that has served me pretty well. The first step here is diagnosing. So, diagnosing the actual problem.
speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
context: Lenny asks Krithika what people should do instead of copying successful marketing playbooks from other companies. Krithika explains her engineering background and how it shaped her systematic approach to marketing. She introduces her four-step framework that starts with diagnosis - systematically identifying the real problem before jumping to solutions. This methodical approach contrasts with the common tendency to immediately implement tactics that worked for other companies without understanding the underlying context and challenges.
text_ko: 저는 마케터가 되기 전에 엔지니어였어요, 그래서 엔지니어식 프레임워크(engineer's framework)를 마케팅 쪽에 조금 적용했어요. 제가 해온 것 중 하나는 제게 꽤 잘 맞았던 4단계 프로세스(four-step process)를 정리하는 거였어요. 여기서 첫 번째 단계는 진단(diagnosing)이에요. 즉 실제 문제를 진단하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我之前是做工程师的，后来才转做市场营销，所以我把一些工程师的思维框架带到了市场这边来。我总结出了一套四步走的方法，用下来效果挺不错的。第一步就是诊断问题，找出真正的问题到底是什么。
text_es: Entonces, yo era ingeniero antes de meterme al marketing, y he traído un poco del enfoque de ingeniero al lado del marketing. Algo que he tratado de hacer es armar un proceso de cuatro pasos que me ha funcionado bastante bien. El primer paso es diagnosticar. O sea, diagnosticar el problema real.

text: And then, this is the critical step. The next one is you have to intentionally take a different path than what everyone else is doing. And so driving a strategy that sort of sets the company apart is really critically important. I think it's so core to the discipline of marketing, ensuring that differentiation in the market.
speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
context: Krithika is explaining the third step of her DATE framework (Diagnose, Analyze, Take a different path, Experiment). After diagnosing the problem and analyzing what competitors are doing, she emphasizes that the crucial step is deliberately choosing a different approach. She argues that differentiation isn't just nice to have - it's fundamental to effective marketing. Rather than trying to execute the same strategies as competitors but slightly better, successful companies must find unique positioning and approaches that set them apart in the marketplace.
text_ko: 그리고 이게 결정적인 단계예요. 다음으로는 의도적으로 모두가 가는 길과는 다른 길을 택해야 해요. 그래서 회사를 차별화시키는 전략(strategy)을 세우고 추진하는 게 정말 중요해요. 저는 시장에서의 차별화(differentiation)를 확보하는 게 마케팅(marketing)이라는 분야의 핵심이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 然后呢，这一步特别关键。接下来你必须要有意识地走一条跟别人不一样的路。所以说，制定一个能让公司脱颖而出的策略真的是太重要了。我觉得这就是营销这门学问的核心所在，就是要确保你在市场上有差异化(differentiation)。
text_es: Y entonces, este es el paso clave. Lo que sigue es que tienes que tomar intencionalmente un camino distinto al que están siguiendo todos los demás. Entonces, impulsar una estrategia que realmente diferencie a la empresa es súper importante. Creo que es fundamental en la disciplina del marketing, asegurar esa diferenciación en el mercado.

text: Really, what you want to be looking at is your impact on either signups if you're a self-serve product, PLG, or in terms of a B2B company, sales leads and revenue that you're driving, pipeline and opportunity that you're driving. So we diagnosed that and we found that for the most part, our paid social channels were doing not much for us.
speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
context: Krithika is sharing a case study from Retool where she applied her diagnostic framework. She had just criticized vanity metrics like clicks and impressions, emphasizing that marketers should focus on business outcomes that actually matter. In this example, she explains how they discovered their paid social channels weren't generating meaningful sales leads or revenue despite potentially showing good engagement numbers. This diagnostic step revealed they needed to invest in completely new marketing engines rather than just scaling existing channels.
text_ko: 정말로 봐야 할 건, 셀프서비스 제품(self-serve product)이거나 제품 주도 성장(product-led growth, PLG) 모델이라면 가입(signups)에 미치는 영향이고, B2B 기업(B2B company)의 경우라면 우리가 만들어내는 영업 리드(sales leads), 매출(revenue), 파이프라인(pipeline)과 오퍼튜니티(opportunity)에 미치는 영향이에요. 그래서 분석해봤더니 대체로 유료 소셜 채널(paid social channels)은 우리한테 별로 효과가 없더라고요.
text_zh: 其实你真正要关注的是你的影响力，如果你是自助服务产品、PLG（产品导向增长）的话，就看注册量；如果是B2B公司的话，就看你带来的销售线索和收入，还有你推动的销售管道(pipeline)和商机。所以我们诊断了一下，发现我们的付费社交渠道基本上没给我们带来什么效果。
text_es: La verdad es que lo que tienes que mirar es tu impacto, ya sea en registros si tienes un producto de autoservicio, PLG, o si eres una empresa B2B, en los leads de ventas y los ingresos que estás generando, el pipeline y las oportunidades que estás creando. Entonces hicimos ese diagnóstico y descubrimos que en su mayoría, nuestros canales de redes sociales pagadas no nos estaban dando casi nada.

text: It seems like there's a playbook for everything, there is a framework for everything, but the reality is you have to spend the hours and the time to really understand your customer, and there is no replacement for that, and there isn't going to be even with the advent of AI.
speaker: Krithika Shankarraman
context: This is Krithika's closing advice to listeners, summarizing her main philosophy about marketing. Throughout the conversation, she has consistently argued against following generic playbooks and frameworks, instead advocating for deep, first-hand customer understanding. She emphasizes that despite the availability of countless marketing frameworks and the emergence of AI tools, there is no substitute for investing significant time and effort in truly comprehending your customers' needs, problems, and behaviors. This hands-on approach forms the foundation of effective marketing strategy.
vocabulary_highlights: there is no replacement for that
text_ko: 모든 일에 플레이북(playbook)이 있고 프레임워크(framework)가 다 있는 것처럼 보이지만, 실제로는 고객을 진짜로 이해하려면 시간과 노력을 들여 직접 파고들어야 해요. 그걸 대신할 방법은 없고, AI(AI)가 등장해도 마찬가지예요.
text_zh: 现在好像什么都有套路，什么都有框架，但实际上你还是得花时间、下功夫去真正了解你的客户，这个是没法替代的，就算AI再发达也一样。
text_es: Parece que hay una guía paso a paso para todo, un marco de referencia (framework) para todo, pero la realidad es que tienes que dedicar las horas y el tiempo para realmente entender a tu cliente, y eso no se puede reemplazar con nada, y no va a cambiar ni siquiera con la llegada de la inteligencia artificial.
